column7: General Information
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column7: Fisher & Paykel Healthcare is a leading designer, manufacturer, and marketer of products and systems for acute and chronic respiratory care, surgery, and the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea. Our medical devices and technologies help clinicians deliver the best possible patient care. They enable patients to transition into less-acute care settings, recover quickly, and avoid more severe conditions.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corporation Limited, Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Limited (NZ), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Asia Limited (NZ), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Asia Investments Limited (NZ), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Americas Investments Limited (NZ), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Limited (UK), Fisher & Paykel Holdings, Inc. (USA), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare SAS (France), Fisher & Paykel Holdings GmbH (Germany), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare MEA Limited (NZ), Fisher & Paykel Healthcare MEA Investments Limited (NZ).

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: The reporting period is from 1 April 2022 to 31 March 2023. Annual reporting cycle.

We have restated our FY2021 and FY2022 Scope 2 emissions to account for the Ministry for the Environment's (New Zealand) latest Measuring Emissions Guide (16 August 2022), which includes revised electricity emissions factors.

External assurance of environmental disclosures provided by ToitÃÂ« Envirocare (no external assurance for other non-financial disclosures). External assurance for financial statements provided by PwC.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Our Hospital product group includes products used in invasive ventilation, noninvasive ventilation, nasal high-flow therapy, anesthesia, and laparoscopic and open surgery. Our Homecare product group includes devices and systems used to treat obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and provide respiratory support in the home. We purchased land for a second New Zealand campus during the reporting period (receiving OIO approval of the transaction in April 2023). We also began the development of a manufacturing facility in China.
FY23 Fisher & Paykel Healthcare had 6,391 full-time employees and 58 part-time employees.
Fisher & Paykel had 135 temporary workers as of 31 March 2023.

The Board has three permanent committees that support the Board by working with management on relevant issues at a suitably \n detailed level and then report back to the Board. There are the Audit & Risk Committee, People & Remuneration Committee, and Quality, Safety & Regulatory Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The Board determines the number of directors by the company's constitution. The constitution requires at least four directors and no more than nine directors and governs the process for appointing and removing directors. When searching for and nominating candidates to act as director, the People & Remuneration Committee takes into account such factors as \nIt is deemed appropriate, including diversity of gender, background, experience and qualifications of the candidate, independence, and the board skills matrix.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: A director is appointed by ordinary resolution of the shareholders, although the Board may fill a casual vacancy. Under the NZX Listing Rules, a director must not hold office (without re-election) past the third annual meeting following the director's appointment or three years, whichever is longer.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board plays a vital role in overseeing our strategic direction. Strong governance from a diverse and experienced Board ensures we can improve patient care and outcomes through inspired and world-leading healthcare solutions, thereby sustainably increasing shareholder value.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board delegates management of the day-to-day affairs and responsibilities of the company to the CEO and executive management to deliver the strategic direction and goals approved by the Board. The Board regularly reviews and assesses our governance structures, policies, and procedures to ensure these meet all legal requirements and ensure we maintain the trust of our customers, suppliers and communities.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: We are committed to transparent reporting of non-financial objectives, such as environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, risk, health and safety, and business strategy. Our annual report references the guidelines and principles the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) set out and includes a GRI-referenced content index.

The Codes cover a range of areas relevant to legal and ethical behaviour, including competing fairly, health and safety, data protection and privacy, working with customers and suppliers, sanctions compliance, responsible marketing, financial records and reporting, continuous disclosure and insider trading, combatting bribery and corruption and interactions with healthcare professionals. It also covers confidentiality, conflicts of interest, receipt of gifts, and corporate opportunities.

The Codes explain how an employee or director can report an actual or suspected breach of the Code. This is also detailed in our Speak Up (or whistle-blowing/protected disclosures) Procedure (launched globally in October 2021), which ensures employees know how to report potentially unethical or illegal behaviour or breaches of our Code of Conduct without fear of retaliation or harassment. Reports can be made to Speak Up Officers within the company or to an independent reporting service managed by Deloitte.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board, with assistance from the Audit & Risk Committee, is responsible for providing overall governance and oversight of the company's environmental and social responsibility practices, including providing strategic direction and consideration of the impacts of climate change. The Audit & Risk Committee reviews the company's risk management framework, which includes environmental and social aspects, and the company's performance on these matters. As part of this, the Committee reviews actual and potential climate-related impacts in addition to our assessment of climate-related scenarios, risks and opportunities.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: We have a performance evaluation procedure related to the performance of the Board, the board committees, and individual directors. The Procedure, following the Board Charter, requires the Board to undertake a two-yearly performance evaluation of itself that compares the performance of the Board with the requirements of the Board Charter, reviews the performance of the Board Committees and individual directors, and affects any improvements to the Board Charter deemed necessary or appropriate.

column7: Employees receive base remuneration packages that are generally benchmarked against similar positions in companies of comparable size and complexity. We use industry remuneration surveys conducted by outside consultants to determine remuneration levels. Generally, remuneration is reviewed annually, and our process supports our intention to pay our people fairly.

column13: We operate in many countries, and our remuneration practices reflect our culture, values and local market conditions. Our employee remuneration programme consists of a base wage or salary, a discretionary component providing the potential for an annual variation based on relevant company performance, and superannuation, life insurance and the opportunity to purchase shares and receive long-term variable remuneration in the form of share options, performance share rights or employee share rights (in certain countries).
column20: Global workforce, Compensation fairness, long-term incentives

column7: The People & Remuneration Committee is responsible for reviewing the remuneration of executive management in consultation with the CEO. Executive management remuneration includes a fixed remuneration package, a discretionary annual variable remuneration (DAVR) component, a long-term variable remuneration (LTVR) component, and the company-wide profit-sharing payment scheme.\t

The ratio of Chief Executive total remuneration to mean Fisher & Paykel Healthcare total remuneration is 39.9:1 (using $92,036.52 as mean employee total remuneration and FY23 Chief Executive total remuneration).

Environmental and social responsibility remains a priority. Multiple teams across the business are working hard to embed our intent of creating a lasting, positive impact on society and the Environment into our way of operating. This report's 'Operating Sustainably' portion outlines our progress in various areas over the past year.

column8: R&D and manufacturing in New Zealand
column13: At two-and-a-half times the size of our current Auckland campus, the land offers much-needed space for expansion over the next 30 to 40 years. These plans reaffirm our confidence in our long-term opportunities and demonstrate our firm commitment to R&D and manufacturing in New Zealand.
column20: Job creation, local communities, economic development

column13: Fisher & Paykel Healthcare has been measuring its carbon footprint since 2012, and we set Science Targets for Scope 1 and 2 emissions back in 2020. We are investing time and energy to develop a long-term carbon reduction plan that is fit for purpose and aligned with net zero CO2e by 2050.
column20: Carbon footprint, science-based targets, net-zero emissions

column8: Internal carbon price and large-scale solar arrays
column13: In the meantime, we continue progressing with ambitious initiatives that move us in the right direction. During the 2023 financial year, this included trialling an internal carbon price and the ongoing installation of large-scale solar arrays to provide electricity at the Mexico manufacturing site.
column20: Internal carbon pricing, renewable energy, sustainability initiatives

column13: Multiple teams across the business are working hard to embed our intent of creating a lasting, positive impact on society and the environment into our way of operating. This report's 'Operating Sustainably' portion outlines our progress in various areas over the past year.
column20: Sustainability integration, positive impact, stakeholder engagement

column7: Precautionary principle of approach:ÃÂ We support a precautionary approach towards environmental management. While we see little apparent risk for our operations, we see an opportunity to help our customers manage this risk through effective product lifecycle management and sustainable design. Had values of Life, Relationships, Internationalism, Commitment, and Originality.
The company is releasing a set of global awareness and training activities for its new policies and procedures.

The company identifies and addresses the negative impacts of legal and ethical conduct, including breaches of the Code of Conduct, unfair competition, data privacy violations, responsible marketing, bribery and corruption, and interactions with healthcare professionals.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Our Speak Up (or whistle-blowing/protected disclosures) Procedure (launched globally in October 2021) ensures employees know how to report potentially unethical or illegal behaviour or breaches of our Code of Conduct without fear of retaliation or harassment. Reports can be made to Speak Up Officers within the company or to an independent reporting service managed by Deloitte.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: As a business, we are committed to doing the right thing. From a social responsibility standpoint, it is important to us and is what our customers, employees, and shareholders find compelling. We have policies and procedures to ensure we conduct our business legally, ethically and socially responsibly.
column20: Social responsibility, ethical business practices, stakeholder value

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Training on our Code of Conduct is undertaken by employees globally and is part of our induction process for new employees. It has been translated into several different languages for our local offices.
column20: Code of Conduct training, ethical behaviour, compliance

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: As of the date of this report, the company complies with all of the recommendations of the NZX Corporate Governance Code dated June 17 2022. The company notes the NZX Corporate Governance Code amendments, which took effect on April 1, 2023.

column7: There have been no significant non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations during the 2023 financial year. There has been no considerable non-compliance with social and economic laws and regulations during the 2023 financial year.

The stakeholders are Employees, Clinicians, Customers, Suppliers, Investors and Communities. We worked with an independent consultant, thinkstep-anz, to obtain feedback from multiple stakeholders. The result is an updated materiality assessment informed by the 2021 GRI Sustainability Reporting Standards principles.
